author: By Harold Isaac and Catherine Porter
title: Haiti Protests Mass U.S. Deportation of Migrants to Country in Crisis
description: Haiti migration officials have asked the United States for a “humanitarian moratorium” even as they receive the first returnees from Texas. “Will we have enough to feed these people?”
content: PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti — The first Haitians deported from a makeshift camp in Texas landed in their home country Sunday amid sweltering heat, anger and confusion, as Haitian officials beseeched the United States to stop the flights because the country is in crisis and cannot handle thousands of homeless deportees.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Booster Shots, France, Fall Books: Your Weekend Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know about the week’s top stories.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Rogers
title: Jill Biden Is Chasing the President’s Most Elusive Campaign Promise: Unity
description: As the president tries to prove that bipartisanship is still possible, the first lady is not standing on the sidelines.
content: WASHINGTON — The summer was a rough one for President Biden.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anton Troianovski and Ivan Nechepurenko
title: Russian Election Shows Declining Support for Putin’s Party
description: With voting in the country neither free nor fair, United Russia is still expected to retain power easily even if its seats in Parliament slip.
content: MOSCOW — Early results in Russia’s parliamentary elections showed a rise in opposition to President Vladimir V. Putin’s governing party, though it was nevertheless expected to cruise easily to victory.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trip Gabriel
title: With Abortion Rights Under Threat, Democrats Hope to Go on Offense
description: Warning of Texas-style laws nationwide, the party believes it can use the issue to turn out suburban women in the Virginia governor’s race this fall and the 2022 midterms.
content: VIRGINIA BEACH — Kenzie Smith is “not big into politics,” she said, and while she votes faithfully in presidential elections, for Democrats, she is less interested in off-year races, such as those seven weeks away in Virginia for governor and the legislature.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Dunne
title: What We Learned From Week 2 of the N.F.L. Season
description: Bill Belichick sees a path toward making the Patriots a dynastic contender again, the Cowboys’ talent got a chance to shine, and Sam Darnold looks … happy.
content: There were no shirtless pictures of Bill Belichick from Barbados gracing your screens this off-season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Devin Gordon and Diante Lee
title: Are the Jets and Giants Watchable Yet?
description: We enlisted two experts — one locally focused, one nationally — to offer readers their opinions.
content: This season, we’ve enlisted two experts — one familiar with the ins and outs of New York’s football teams, the other a nationally focused football analyst — to answer an essential question as a service to readers: Are these teams good yet?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: What’s Going On in This Picture? | Sept. 20, 2021
description: Look closely at this image, stripped of its caption, and join the moderated conversation about what you and other students see.
content: 1. After looking closely at the image above (or at the full-size image), think about these three questions:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez and Eduardo Medina
title: Remains Believed to Belong to Missing Woman in Van Mystery Are Found
description: The authorities said they had found human remains in Wyoming consistent with a description of Gabrielle Petito, 22. She was reported missing after he returned home alone from a cross-country van trip.
content: Human remains believed to belong to a Florida woman reported missing after her fiancé returned home from a monthslong van trip without her were found in a national park in Wyoming on Sunday, the F.B.I. said at a news conference.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tish Harrison Warren
title: How Silence Became a Luxury Product
description: Our lives are loud — and too often it costs money to escape the noise.
content: Recently, I wanted to find a moment to journal, pray, and simply be still, so I went to a riverbank near my home. I sat listening to birds, eyeing the languid joy of sunbathing turtles, charting fallen leaves eddying in the green current. A roar broke the silence. A leaf blower. I tried to find a quieter spot, but leaf blowers seemed to follow me. Everywhere. It was like some secret society of leaf blowers conspired against me. I kept looking, but quiet was elusive. Wherever I went I found the whooshes of road noise, the clack-clack-clacking of construction, or the blare of televisions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: SpaceX astronauts will get a health check after splashdown.
description: While the Inspiration4 crew was only in orbit for three days, doctors will performing screenings to make sure they are well.
content: When astronauts return to Earth from space, they can experience a number of health and physical issues after they land — a result of living without gravity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Judith Shulevitz
title: Ruth Ozeki’s Borgesian, Zen Buddhist Parable of Consumerism
description: In “The Book of Form and Emptiness,” the characters are so preoccupied with material possessions that objects come to life all around them.
content: THE BOOK OF FORM AND EMPTINESS By Ruth Ozeki
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabeth Vincentelli
title: A Cabaret Star and an Opera Star Walk Onto a Stage …
description: The punchline is “Only an Octave Apart,” featuring the unlikely collaborators Justin Vivian Bond and Anthony Roth Costanzo at St. Ann’s Warehouse.
content: “This show has been 10 years in the making,” the countertenor Anthony Roth Costanzo said recently.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Koblin
title: Michael K. Williams could win an acting award posthumously.
description: The actor, who was found dead on Sept. 6, is nominated for best supporting actor in a drama for “Lovecraft Country,” and is a slight favorite to win.
content: Michael K. Williams, the beloved star of “The Wire” who was found dead on Sept. 6, is nominated for best supporting actor in a drama for the recently canceled HBO series “Lovecraft Country.” If he does win — and he is a slight favorite over Tobias Menzies from “The Crown” — it will not be because Emmys voters wanted to give him the award posthumously. The Emmy voting period ended before Williams’s death.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Esau McCaulley
title: The Dangerous Politics of ‘We Will Not Forgive’
description: America has spent 20 years vowing revenge for terrorism. There’s a better path.
content: President Biden, in the somber tone and muted dress indicative of responding to tragedy, addressed the nation late last month. The Kabul airport attack had just claimed the lives of 13 American troops and over 60 Afghan civilians. He spoke movingly of the ultimate sacrifice made by our servicemen and -women. Then he turned his attention to our enemies. He said, “We will not forgive. We will not forget. We will hunt you down and make you pay.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Madrid is set to remove most of its restrictions on Monday.
description: The 14-day infection rate in Spain has fallen to its lowest level since August 2020.
content: Madrid will remove most of its pandemic restrictions on Monday amid a general easing of lockdown rules in Spain after the country’s coronavirus infection rate fell to its lowest level in more than a year.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Texas Lawmakers, After Shift to Right, Plan More of Same
description: Quotation of the Day for Sunday, September 19, 2021.
content: “Texans are watching their state government that is consumed with these partisan debates over abortion and election reform, but they’re actually living in a state where schools can’t give clear safety guidance on Covid. The concern is that the conservative faction has gone too far and is damaging our state’s reputation.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Kestenbaum
title: The Trump Prophets Regroup
description: When you are in the business of prophecy, what do you do when prophecy fails?
content: This spring, the media mogul Stephen E. Strang made an unusual apology to readers in the pages of his glossy magazine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: The ‘Murdaugh Murders’: What to Know About the South Carolina Mystery
description: The unsolved killings of a lawyer’s wife and son have brought new scrutiny to three other deaths in recent years.
content: ISLANDTON, S.C. — The unsolved killing of a mother and son. Millions of dollars in stolen funds. Fresh investigations into a fatal boat crash and a housekeeper’s deadly fall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tariro Mzezewa
title: Alabama Begins Removing Racist Language From Its Constitution
description: Many outdated provisions have long since been invalidated, but the language that was specifically intended to enshrine white supremacy has remained.
content: The last time Alabama politicians rewrote their state Constitution, back in 1901, their aspirations were explicitly racist: “to establish white supremacy in this state.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Anthes
title: A New Covid Testing Model Aims to Spare Students From Quarantine
description: More school districts are embracing “test-to-stay” protocols that allow uninfected close contacts to remain in the classroom.
content: When the schools in Marietta, Ga., opened their doors on Aug. 3, the highly contagious Delta variant was sweeping across the South, and children were not being spared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talya Minsberg
title: For a TikTok Running Star, It’s All Uphill From Here
description: Erin Azar, a.k.a. Mrs. Space Cadet on TikTok, invited followers to join her, “a slightly overweight person who drinks too much beer,” as she trains for a marathon. She didn’t anticipate millions would respond.
content: Every one of Erin Azar’s runs from her home in central Pennsylvania starts with an uphill. And it makes her want to die.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isaac Aronow and Doug Mennella
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: SUNDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas
title: Fauci urges Americans not to get booster shots until they are eligible.
description: Dr. Fauci is also defending President Biden’s decision to release a plan for Covid boosters before regulators had given their recommendations.
content: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci, the nation’s top infectious disease doctor, defended President Biden’s decision last month to announce the availability of Covid booster shots before regulators had weighed in, and he urged vaccinated Americans to wait until they were eligible for an extra shot before getting one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kimiko de Freytas-Tamura
title: Footage Reveals New Details in Tourist Melee at N.Y.C. Restaurant
description: Three Black women from Texas were arrested, but a lawyer for one called it “mutual combat” after they were called a racial slur.
content: New information emerged on Saturday about a brawl outside a popular Italian restaurant in Manhattan that raises questions about initial accounts of the altercation, in which the police said they arrested three women from Texas after they attacked a hostess who had asked them to provide proof of their vaccination status.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rick Rojas and William DeShazer
title: In the Heart of Nashville, Rolling Parties Rage at Every Stoplight
description: As Nashville’s popularity has grown, so has the “transportainment” business — a motley assortment including old buses, farm tractors and a truck with a hot tub. Many think it has gotten out of hand.
content: NASHVILLE — The John Deere tractor pulled onto Broadway and rumbled into the madness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tropical Storm Peter Forms in the Atlantic Ocean
description: The 16th named storm of the 2021 season formed in the open ocean, east of the Caribbean.
content: Tropical Storm Peter formed in the Atlantic Ocean east of the Caribbean on Sunday, forecasters said, announcing the 16th named storm of the 2021 season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Texas Doctor Says He Performed an Abortion in Defiance of New State Law
description: In an opinion essay in The Washington Post titled “Why I violated Texas’s extreme abortion ban,” Dr. Alan Braid wrote, “I am taking a personal risk, but it’s something I believe in strongly.”
content: A Texas doctor disclosed on Saturday that he had performed an abortion in defiance of a new state law that bans most abortions after six weeks of pregnancy, setting up a potential test case of one of the most restrictive abortion measures in the nation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aurelien Breeden
title: When Covid-19 Stole Their Smell, These Experts Lost Much More
description: French perfumers, sommeliers and winemakers with coronavirus infections are sometimes deprived of a crucial tool: their high-performing noses.
content: PARIS — Hélène Barre, 35, lost her sense of smell when she fell ill with Covid-19 in November, a condition known as anosmia. Her slow recovery was plagued by disturbing distortions: Peanuts smelled like shrimp, raw ham like butter, rice like Nutella. The phantom scent of something burning still bothers her for hours at a time.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emmanuel Morgan
title: Carl Nassib Made History, but Also a Big Play
description: Last week Nassib, 28, became the first openly gay player to compete in an N.F.L. game. Teammates, the news media and observers casually noted the feat, then cheered his game-changing play.
content: One of the most significant cultural milestones in the recent history of North American sports occurred with about as much pomp and circumstance as a shrug of the shoulders.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vimal Patel
title: Military Jet Crashes in Texas Backyard, Injuring 2 Pilots
description: Three homes were damaged and three residents treated for minor injuries, the Fort Worth Fire Department said. “It could have been a lot worse,” a fire chief said.
content: A military training jet crashed into a backyard in Lake Worth, Texas, on Sunday, injuring the plane’s two pilots, damaging at least three homes and causing dozens of homes to lose power, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Sept. 19, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Sunday, Sept. 19, 2021.
content: An article on Page 44 this weekend about dance events this fall misstates the last name of a founder of FLOCK. He is Florian Lochner, not Lockner.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Walker
title: Biden Administration Seeks to Expand Telehealth in Rural America
description: New funding will allow more medical appointments to take place via video in rural communities, where some of the nation’s oldest and sickest patients live.
content: The roughly 15 percent of the population living in rural America includes some of the oldest and sickest patients in the country — a disparity that has grown more stark during the coronavirus pandemic. The Biden administration is investing more in telemedicine, whose use has grown sharply during the pandemic, as a way to improve their access to care.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elisabetta Povoledo
title: A Giant Violin Floats Down Venice’s Grand Canal
description: This 39-foot-long instrument, built by local artisans and carrying musicians performing a live concert, sets a course for the future.
content: VENICE — In its 1,600-odd years, any number of phantasmagorical vessels have floated down Venice’s Grand Canal, often during regattas or elaborate ceremonies dedicated to the sea. On Saturday morning, a decidedly unusual head-turner took a spin: a gigantic violin, carrying a string quartet playing Vivaldi’s “Four Seasons.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Israel Captures Last 2 Palestinian Inmates Still Free After Prison Break
description: Six prisoners had tunneled out of a maximum-security facility on Sept. 6, in an embarrassment for Israel.
content: JERUSALEM — Israel on Sunday captured the last of the six Palestinian inmates who escaped a maximum-security prison nearly two weeks ago, ending an episode that Israelis saw as a humiliation of their security establishment and Palestinians celebrated as a rare black eye for the Israeli occupation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charles M. Blow
title: White Evangelicals Shun Morality for Power
description: They’ve been a “political arm of the Republican Party” for decades now.
content: Evangelical Christians castigated Bill Clinton in wake of his “improper relationship” with the White House intern Monica Lewinsky. He had sinned. He would be stoned.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ilya Yablokov
title: There’s a Reason Putin Keeps Winning
description: The Kremlin’s propaganda system, lurid and spurious, is central to the president’s power.
content: Elections in Russia are always tricky for the Kremlin. Offer too much choice, and citizens may pick the wrong candidates. Offer too little, and the underlying authoritarianism of the regime becomes grimly apparent.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alanis Thames
title: Alabama Barely Edges Out Florida in SEC Opener
description: Florida’s second-half surge took the Crimson Tide by surprise but was not enough to topple No. 1 Alabama.
content: GAINESVILLE, Fla. — Ben Hill Griffin Stadium has quieted down. A game that was much closer than many expected had the Gators’ fans permeating the air with deafening chants as they made one last effort to will their team past the Alabama Crimson Tide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexandra Stevenson and Cao Li
title: Evergrande Gave Workers a Choice: Loan Us Cash or Lose Your Bonus
description: The Chinese property giant owes $300 billion and is on the hook for as many as 1.6 million apartments. It may owe tens of thousands of its employees money, too.
content: When the troubled Chinese property giant Evergrande was starved for cash earlier this year, it turned to its own employees with a strong-arm pitch: Those who wanted to keep their bonuses would have to give Evergrande a short-term loan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: France recalls its U.S. and Australian ambassadors.
content: Relations between France and the U.S. have sunk to their lowest level in decades, after the U.S. and Australia secretly negotiated a plan to build nuclear submarines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Fuhrer
title: JoJo Siwa Wants to Be ‘a Role Model for People Who Love Love’
description: At 18, the “Dance Moms” and internet star is returning to reality TV as half of the first same-sex partnership on “Dancing With the Stars.”
content: A few years ago, JoJo Siwa emerged as a tween wonder on the reality show “Dance Moms,” known for her brassy one-liners, rapid-fire pirouettes and rainbow-hued ensembles topped with huge hair bows.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Nabisco Workers End Weekslong Strike After Reaching New Contract
description: The impasse began in August after members of the Bakery, Confectionery, Tobacco Workers and Grain Millers Union objected to changes in shift lengths and overtime rules.
content: A weekslong strike by Nabisco employees in five states ended on Saturday, as their union announced that its members had overwhelmingly approved a four-year contract with the parent company of the maker of Oreos, Ritz Crackers and other snacks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Traci Carl
title: Chris Rock says he has Covid.
description: The comedian shared the news on social media and told his followers to get vaccinated.
content: Chris Rock told his social media followers on Sunday that he is sick with Covid-19 after a breakthrough infection, and the comedian urged people to get vaccinated.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katrin Bennhold
title: Merkel’s Children: Living Legacies Called Angela, Angie and Sometimes Merkel
description: For some refugee families who traveled to Germany during the migrant crisis of 2015 and 2016, gratitude for Chancellor Angela Merkel’s decision to welcome them comes via a namesake.
content: WÜLFRATH, Germany — Hibaja Maai gave birth three days after arriving in Germany.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giulia Heyward
title: Mississippi’s governor plays down state’s high death rate.
description: Gov. Tate Reeves calls the death rate a “lagging indicator” of how Mississippi is faring during the pandemic.
content: Gov. Tate Reeves of Mississippi on Sunday downplayed his state’s high Covid death rate, calling it an inadequate benchmark to measure the pandemic’s toll in the state.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: John Shelby Spong, 90, Dies; Sought to Open Up the Episcopal Church
description: Bishop Spong pushed for women in the clergy and same-sex marriage, and he called on his followers to reject “supernatural” aspects of Christianity.
content: John Shelby Spong, a charismatic Episcopal bishop who pushed his followers to accept women and L.G.B.T.Q. clergy, and who later called on them to reject sacrosanct ideas like Jesus’ virgin birth and the existence of heaven and hell, died on Sept. 12 at his home in Richmond, Va. He was 90.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: The Yankees’ Roller Coaster of a Season Hits Another Big Dip
description: Fighting for their postseason life, the Yankees got embarrassed at home, again, despite having Gerrit Cole on the mound.
content: The Yankees are a fourth-place team, like the Miami Marlins, the Chicago Cubs, the Colorado Rockies, the Kansas City Royals and the Los Angeles Angels. Those teams have losing records and no hope of the playoffs. The Yankees, in the more rugged American League East, are part of the pennant race.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman and Reid J. Epstein
title: Beto O’Rourke Draws Closer to Entering Texas Governor’s Race
description: Mr. O’Rourke has been calling Democratic leaders in Texas to tell them he is seriously considering challenging Gov. Greg Abbott in 2022.
content: HOUSTON — Beto O’Rourke, the former El Paso congressman who became a darling of Democrats after nearly defeating Senator Ted Cruz in 2018, is inching closer to announcing a run for governor of Texas, according to three people who have spoken with him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Rachel Fabi
title: Solving a Mystery
description: Pao Roy digs deep.
content: MONDAY PUZZLE — Congratulations to Pao Roy on making their New York Time Crossword debut! This puzzle is an ideal Monday solve: The theme is straightforward but original, the entries are fun but accessible and the clues are colorful but simple.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bahr
title: Here’s how to watch the Emmy Awards tonight.
description: The ceremony begins at 8 p.m. Eastern on CBS and you can watch online via cbs.com, or if you’re a CBS subscriber, via the CBS app with a cable login.
content: There’s sure to be both drama and comedy at the 73rd annual Primetime Emmy Awards, which will be mostly an in-person edition of the show. Hosted by Cedric the Entertainer, the comedian and star of CBS’s “The Neighborhood,” the awards will be handed out Sunday night in Los Angeles before a limited audience, and will honor the pandemic-era television programs that got us through lockdown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Tropical Storm Rose Forms West of Africa
description: The storm, the third to develop in less than a week, became the 17th named storm of the busy 2021 hurricane season.
content: Tropical Storm Rose formed west of Africa on Sunday, becoming the 17th named storm of the busy 2021 Atlantic hurricane season and the third to develop in less than a week.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘My Heart Started Pounding When I Realized I Was That Someone’
description: Distressed on the Dumbo pier, meeting a college basketball legend and more reader tales of New York City in this week’s Metropolitan Diary.
content: Dear Diary:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Raphael Minder
title: Thousands Evacuated as Canary Island Volcano Erupts
description: A volcano on the island of La Palma spewed lava and smoke, prompting an evacuation of thousands and forcing the Spanish prime minister to delay a trip to New York.
content: A volcano erupted Sunday on the Spanish island of La Palma, spewing lava and a thick column of smoke and prompting the authorities to evacuate thousands of residents from nearby towns.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By C. J. Hughes
title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Recent residential sales in New York City and the region.
content: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Laura Collins-Hughes
title: Hope (and Ian McKellen) Lured Me to Britain. Was It Worth the Risk?
description: I made the calculations before I traveled, and decided to go for it. Double masked, I stepped off the plane and set off for a week of theater.
content: LONDON — I did not actually see the heckler, but I can tell you what I heard from down the block: a man’s voice through what sounded like a megaphone, jeering at the crowd lined up outside the Gillian Lynne Theater for Andrew Lloyd Webber’s “Cinderella.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kenneth Chang
title: Inspiration4 Astronauts Beam After Return From 3-Day Journey to Orbit
description: The mission hinted at what space travel could look like in a more accessible future, while remaining in reach now to only the richest of the rich.
content: After three days in orbit, a physician assistant, a community college professor, a data engineer and the billionaire who financed their trip arrived back on Earth, heralding a new era of space travel with a dramatic and successful Saturday evening landing in the Atlantic Ocean.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Bills Offense Cruises in Low Gear to Win in Miami
description: In a rout of Miami, the Bills offense did not even need Josh Allen’s best. He still finished 17 of 33 passing for 179 yards and two touchdowns to take the lead in the A.F.C. East.
content: Every starting quarterback in the A.F.C. East was chosen in the top half of the first round within the last four N.F.L. drafts, infusing a bonanza of dynamic young talent into a division that could be — emphasis on could — sneaky competitive this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ruth Maclean
title: Fighting a Pandemic, While Launching Africa’s Health Revolution
description: Public health in Africa has been a story of neglect and dependency, says John Nkengasong, the first director of the Africa Centers for Disease Control. But he’s on a mission to turn things around.
content: When Dr. John Nkengasong took the job as the first head of Africa’s new Centers for Disease Control in 2017, part of the continent had just emerged from a devastating Ebola outbreak. Less than three years later, Covid-19 hit.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse Drucker and Danny Hakim
title: How Accounting Giants Craft Favorable Tax Rules From Inside Government
description: Lawyers from top accounting firms do brief stints in the Treasury Department, with the expectation of big raises when they return.
content: For six years, Audrey Ellis and Adam Feuerstein worked together at PwC, the giant accounting firm, helping the world’s biggest companies avoid taxes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ezra Klein
title: The Economic Mistake the Left Is Finally Confronting
description: The left needs to think as much about supply as it does about demand.
content: The words “supply side” are coded, in American politics, as right wing. They summon the ghost of Arthur Laffer, the history of Republicans promising that cutting taxes on the rich will encourage the nation’s dispirited John Galts to work both smarter and harder, leading economies to boom and revenues to rise. This has made it vaguely disreputable to worry about the supply side of the economy. It’s as if the nonsense of phrenology had made it sordid for doctors to treat disorders of the brain.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Coral Davenport
title: This Powerful Democrat Linked to Fossil Fuels Will Craft the U.S. Climate Plan
description: Senator Joe Manchin is already a crucial swing vote in the Democrats’ sweeping budget bill. But he will also write the details of its climate change program.
content: WASHINGTON — Joe Manchin, the powerful West Virginia Democrat who chairs the Senate energy panel and earned half a million dollars last year from coal production, is preparing to remake President Biden’s climate legislation in a way that tosses a lifeline to the fossil fuel industry — despite urgent calls from scientists that countries need to quickly pivot away from coal, gas and oil to avoid a climate catastrophe.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matshidiso Moeti
title: Rich Countries Worry About Booster Shots. They Should Be Worried About Africa.
description: Just 20 percent of people in low- and lower-middle-income countries have had a Covid-19 vaccine dose — versus 80 percent in richer countries.
content: As the rich world rolls out Covid-19 booster shots, hundreds of millions of Africans remain dangerously exposed, still awaiting their first vaccine dose. This not only adds to the litany of harsh disparities we’ve seen around this virus, but it is also a scandalous injury to global solidarity and vaccine equity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anthony Tommasini
title: The New York Philharmonic Returns, in the Midst of Transitions
description: As the orchestra’s season opens, its music director announced he would step down, its hall is under renovation and it’s still trying to diversify.
content: The New York Philharmonic’s concert on Friday was not just a heartening return to Lincoln Center for America’s oldest orchestra, 556 days after its last performance there.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kessler
title: The Week in Business: A Milestone in Space Tourism
description: Plus, a tax plan is proposed and the government will weigh in on booster shots.
content: A SpaceX rocket carrying four Americans blasted off from the Kennedy Space Center in Florida on Wednesday. The orbital spaceflight was the first to carry only passengers who weren’t professional astronauts, a milestone for the space tourism industry. In addition to SpaceX, which Elon Musk founded, Jeff Bezos’ Blue Origin and Richard Branson’s Virgin Galactic plan to offer commercial spaceflights. But the latest flight differed from the short jaunts that Mr. Bezos and Mr. Branson took to space in July. The crew orbited the planet for three days.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Sunday Read: ‘The Composer at the Frontier of Movie Music’
description: Nicholas Britell’s scores — for “Succession,” “Moonlight” and “The Underground Railroad,” among others — suggest whole new ways of writing for film and television.
content: You have almost certainly heard Nicholas Britell’s music, even if you don’t know his name. More than any other contemporary composer, he appears to have the whole of music history at his command, shifting easily between vocabularies, often in the same film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyssa Lukpat
title: Stabilized Notre-Dame Cathedral Is on Track for 2024 Reopening, Officials Say
description: The restoration effort is seeking to meet President Emmanuel Macron’s ambitious plan to reopen the cathedral five years after it was ravaged by a fire — just in time for the 2024 Olympics in Paris.
content: Two and a half years after a fire ravaged the centuries-old Cathedral of Notre-Dame in the heart of Paris, the building has been secured enough to start the rebuilding process, which is expected to be completed in 2024, according to the French authorities.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Read the Letter to President Biden
description: Dozens of human rights and other advocacy groups urge President Biden to back a $25 billion investment that would produce 8 billion Covid-19 vaccine doses within a year.
content: Dozens of human rights and other advocacy groups urge President Biden to back a $25 billion investment that would produce 8 billion Covid-19 vaccine doses within a year.

author: By Reuters and The Associated Press
title: Inspiration4 Civilian Crew Returns to Earth After 3 Days in Orbit
description: The SpaceX capsule, carrying the first crew ever to go into orbit without a professional astronaut aboard, splashed down in the Atlantic Ocean off Florida’s coast on Saturday.
content: The SpaceX capsule, carrying the first crew ever to go into orbit without a professional astronaut aboard, splashed down in the Atlantic Ocean off Florida’s coast on Saturday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sam Sifton
title: What to Cook This Week
description: Start with a Times classic: Marian Burros’s recipe for a delicious plum torte.
content: Good morning. The New York Times published Marian Burros’s recipe for plum torte (above) in 1983, and did so again every September for six years. Requests for copies of that recipe continued to flood in through the 1990s, but it wasn’t until the birth of New York Times Cooking in the fall of 2014 that we could give it a permanent home. It’s a true taste of the shoulder season between summer and fall, and one of the greatest easy desserts of all time, a perfect Sunday project. Please make it with whatever fruit you can manage today, and raise a glass to Marian when you do. We walk in her footsteps every day.
source.name: The New York Times
